segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 Hello everybody, I really have a hard task because this is the first presentation
after the dinner and this is the second day of the conference and my objective
is not to allow you to fall asleep.
Hopefully this will be something interesting. Very enigmatic. Everybody is
hearing me well? Yep, at least somebody responded. My very enigmatic title, we
need a major step in maturing security. I will explain that in a few
slides. Just a quick disclaimer that all the stuff that I will present in this
presentation and on the following slides is my opinion, nobody else. Not my wife,
not my employee, not my line manager, not my friend of my line manager or
whatever. All the stuff on this presentation is intended for education
purpose only. Feel free to be educated and no animals were harmed during the
whole process and research that was done. Who am I for those who don't know me?
I'm working for more than 12 years in the security and until last year I was
working on the blue team. In the blue team I graduated physics and I'm very
grateful for having that point in time when I was learning
physics because actually it occurs that applying all the rules that we learn
during studying physics applied very well to IT security,
especially that one like you want to test if something is stable, just shake
it. If it will break it, it wasn't secure enough. As I said, for the last
year I'm trying to be a red teamer, so I'm gaining the experience as a red
teamer, but deeply in my heart I'm a blue teamer, so I'm always thinking
even when I'm breaking something or running a cobalt strike, I'm always
thinking about the blue defense side. So, the real problem that I would like
to discuss here is the supply chain attack problem. So, basically the
problem, how can we make secure or more secure or fix some issues
regarding shipping untrusted piece of software into our infrastructure? I know
this is really a good buzzword for the past two years, but I will try to avoid
buzzwords and BS in my presentation. So, the motivation for this presentation
started one and a half year ago, a few days after the SolarWings incidents. How
many of you know what is SolarWings about? Raise your hand. A majority. So,
very quickly, SolarWings is a software that is used in your network. It is a
software that is being run in privilege endpoints, and basically the attacker was
able to compromise the pipeline that is used to create that
software, the binaries of that software, and by compromising that part, it is
really big simplification, they were able to implant malicious components
into the software that was later on installed. They were, the malicious
implant was present in the binaries for at least half a year, and it was
installed in multiple institutions. And soon after the event called
SolarWings hack, the discussion on one of the social, professional social network
portals started with this sentence, like the SolarWings hacks shows that the
automatic patching is not always a good idea, blah, blah, blah, and very obvious and
very correct sentence that you are responsible for what is being installed
on your network. But the biggest problem in the supply chain attack is that, yes,
you are responsible, but the garbage that you receive and you need to install on
your network is being delivered by someone else, and there's no way that you
can verify, continuously verify the trust, especially that you have, if you have
multiple vendors that are supplying multiple things for you. So, I responded
quickly, okay, how on earth can you, what kind of process can you apply to be sure
to ensure yourself or your organization or to detect malicious intents in the
software that is being shipped to you? Like, the only thing that came to my mind,
okay, I can take the binaries, I can install it on the sandbox environment, I
can employ me or my friends to reverse engineer the software, analyze byte by
byte every function that is there, and then I will be able to, in majority, of
course, claim that, okay, I didn't see anything suspicious. If you go to the
doctor, the doctor will never say to you, okay, you're healthy. The doctor
will always tell you, I don't see anything suspicious. For me, you are
not looking sick. They will not tell you that you're 100% healthy because you
may not be healthy. So, even if I would reverse spend, like, half a year on
reverse engineering, I wouldn't feel comfortable on telling somebody else
that I definitely certified that this binary, especially huge binary, is
definitely safe and free from debuggers. And the discussion continues. I'm not
saying that the manual installation is the answer, and the guy proposed three
things. Check if the update is critical or not, and not install it. Like, the
whole idea of shipping the updates quickly is to install them, especially if
the software is high-privileged software, and in the most cases, vendors are not
providing updates because they just, you know, okay, let's release the update. This
is the 22nd of the middle of the summer, let's just release the update. They're
releasing update because they fixed something, probably. Maybe cosmetic things
like user interface button was moved left, or maybe a security issue. To check
on the sandbox, if there's nothing suspicious, like, I deeply believe that
sandbox approach is working, but I will give a huge bottle of very pricey beer
to person that would be able to run a very complex software on the sandbox, and
point a finger, okay, this is a malicious intent. For all the hundreds of the
behavioral things that were registered, like access to the disk, access to the
memory, access to the registry, and all the other interactions, they will be able
to point the finger and say, oh, this is definitely malicious because this IP
address starts from 5. And to ensure that no external communication is being
allowed, and this is very problematic because, for example, the solar wings
needed a lot of network communication, of course, local communication, but if you,
nowadays, it is hard to have a software that doesn't require network
communication. Like, I don't know, most of them require, so even, for example, for
downloading the updates. So, yeah, this was perfect shot, like, don't install updates,
run your software on sandbox, and definitely this will fix the problem of
supply chain attacks. No. And again, if you try to discover what is the problem
with supply chain attacks, that's the problem. You have a third party that you
cannot trust that is supplying you stuff, and you need to run it on your
environment. And, as I said, running stuff and analyzing the results, maybe if you're
running malware and you definitely know what you're looking for. And it was a
moment when corporate approach kicked in. I was in my tie, I was sitting in my shirt,
in my corporate desk, and my approach changes. We don't have problems, we have
challenges. You're not sleeping, nice. So, I asked myself, okay, I can argue on the
LinkedIn, like everybody can do, but this is not moving us anywhere. Let's start
thinking, okay, how actually we can approach that problem. So, first thing of
problem solving, we need to well define what is actually the problem. So, let's start by
trying to articulate what is the problem. The problem is, who can provide the data
about expected behavior of the software? And, of course, the obvious answer here is,
like, you don't need to spend a lot of time on thinking, vendor, because they are building the
software. So, let's do this social experiment. Ask the vendor. So, you're opening Outlook,
starting our urgent request from our security department. Please provide the description,
what is the expected behavior of your software? Let's assume that this is simple software,
like, you know, business calculation or something like that. Regards, full bar,
sending the email, waiting a few days, waiting a few more days, and the answer is coming,
we are receiving the document with a logo. Second page, company mission. Second page,
term, the list of things that will be in the document, and the description why this product
is very special, and marketing description, what this stuff is doing, claiming to be a
behavior description, and the Gartner Square pointing, like, we're here, and we are very
unique, and the statement that you need to think before printing this document. Like,
I think majority of the people that are working in the big organizations would agree with me,
that, like, this is something that you will get if you will ask vendors that way, like,
provide me the description, you will get the PDF, maybe, maybe a word file, maybe a link to
the website with all that very important information, and this is not moving us anywhere
again. So, the real problem is not who can provide the data, because the vendor, this is the obvious
answer, but we just need to maybe ask more precisely for the data. So, okay, we're creating
another email, because this is response for the forward of the response, please provide the list
of domain IP addresses that your software needs to connect in order to work, like, they just focus
on IP addresses. What you will get, let's, like, make a vote, maybe there's something that you would
like to propose. Not a PDF, you will get an Excel file with a list of the domains. Okay, this is
better, because you can select the column, copy to the text file, and you will have the list of
things that you need to look for, or the opposite, you will get the list of the things that shouldn't
worry you, but this is only this one software. Is it scalable? No. Did you get the answer? Partially,
yes, but only for the network connectivity. So, let's move forward. How a responsible entity, and
we assume here that this is a vendor, can provide the data about expected behavior of the software,
and the side question, what is the behavior? So, let's pause here, and think about fixing the
supply chain problem in modern way. We don't need machine learning, we don't need sandboxing, we don't
need blockchain stuff and deception, because we already have too many security software on the
market. We have a network security protection, prevention, we have network intrusion detection,
network intrusion prevention, we have pattern-based detection on the network, and on the host, and
inside the memory even. We have endpoint protection, signature-based, behavioral-based, stuff that is
responsible just for monitoring and forwarding the data about the behavior to the central server,
then to process it and apply the rules. Of course, we have stuff that is based on blockchain and
artificial intelligence, but this is useless. But this all stuff that I enlisted, and probably most
of you are working on daily basis with that kind of software, is ineffective alone. Like a quotation
from the Shrek, the security is like onion, you need to have liars. So, you need to have liars of
security products. You have an endpoint protection, because if the network protection will fail,
maybe the endpoint protection will pick up the attack and alert you, and maybe stop the attack.
All the stuff that I listed here is very vendor-specific, like you are configuring the stuff
in a very vendor-specific way. Most probably, this is a web interface that you need to click.
Even if you apply fancy rules like, okay, let's combine detection of a specific execution path,
etc. You are putting that knowledge and that configuration in a web interface. Maybe in
some cases you have a configuration file being uploaded, maybe. But this is very vendor-specific,
and definitely you cannot just ship this configuration when you're changing, I don't know,
antivirus vendor from one to another. You cannot merge the configuration from one place to another,
because this is vendor-specific. Even if you probably use the button export configuration,
you will end up with binary crap that is only parsable by this specific software. So, in the
same category, like antivirus endpoint protection or network protection, the functionality is even
heavily inconsistent. There's no, like, one baseline that we should look for. There's no
list of events that we should look at on the operating system level. Most probably, the majority
of the security solutions are logging things like, I don't know, create process activity.
Most security processes are logging the network activity. But, for example, and this is an open
question, I never saw a security product that was logging create process function call and the
flag if the process is being created, suspended or not. But everybody who was working on pair
hollowing method knows that this is like the obvious way to detect that. And I didn't saw
any kind of functionality on the market. Of course, there's an exception. Most of those security stuff
is ingesting IOCs. But this is the result of the IOC becoming industry standard in terms of
digesting things. A side question here, how do you store your configuration? You have firewalls,
you have stateless firewalls, stateful firewalls, new generation firewalls, new generation web 3.0
firewalls, endpoint protection, antivirus, EDR, host-based firewall, application-wide listing
rules, URLs and whatever. You have multiple layers. And how do you store the configuration
of those solutions? Most probably, a case study based on firewall, good old, sorry, this was the
next slide. In most cases, in big organization, the configuration is stored in the series of
word documents that are describing the changes that are you applying one by one. Maybe the
appliance is holding the recent version of the rule set configuration. And the only
copy, cold copy of that is if you are making a backup, of course, you're making a backup or
snapshot. As I said before, most probably there's no way to switch the vendor. If you will,
if you, for example, just switch the vendor of the firewall, like switch Palo Alto to Cisco,
Cisco Palo Alto, merging the rule set is a bit challenging. And there's no way that you will
find a provider on the market that will say, okay, we will merge one and one and you will,
we will guarantee the functionality. Anyone storing that kind of configuration again managed
to do that in the text files. So, you're sleeping or nobody's doing that. Let's get back to the
real problem. So, let's apply again the corporate approach to solve the problem. Background is,
how can we get the information about the intended behavior of the software? Current situation is
that as I showed and nobody objected. If we will ask vendor, we'll get word documents or PDFs. This
is completely useless crap. What is our target? We want to get the knowledge that's about the
behavior, about the expected behavior and the way that the computers and the humans can read it,
parse it and consume it. The root cause is most probably there is no well-defined format to
exchange that kind of information. What are the countermeasures? Let's propose the format.
Let's do it, like we did that years ago. We created a IOC standard, like how can we exchange the
knowledge about behavioral events that indicates the infrastructure being compromised. It's working,
we are exchanging that data. We even have a fancy protocols of exchanging that data.
The implementation plan, let's make a POC, ask people about the opinion, put stuff on the GitHub
and get drinks. So, I'm introducing now the indicators of normality, the things that is
quite obvious consequence of indicators of compromise. Why not indicators of compromise?
Because if you are detecting indicator of compromises in the neural network, as I said,
this is already a bad situation. So, we need to reverse the process. Why application whitelisting
is working? Because you're whitelisting the application, you know what you're whitelisting,
you're not blacklisting things because you don't know what you need to blacklist, but you may know
what you want to whitelist. Why? What do we want to achieve? We want to achieve the consistent way
of describing the expected behavior. I'm repeating that like a third time or something, and it needs
to be exchangeable. It needs to be possible for both computers and humans, because otherwise,
people won't be able to assess if this set of rules or set of description is accurate or not.
It should be a primary golden source for virus security liars. Like, if we have this source of
description, we later on can export or extract stuff from this configuration. So, from this
golden source to our endpoint configuration and the endpoint firewall, EDR or whatever
fancy software you are using. And by defining the entities that we expect as being a description of
the behavior, we can have consistent expectations from the vendors. For example, if you have a very
obvious description that we want to have the ability to monitor network security, we can expect
that if we will onboard a vendor, we are expecting that this product needs to monitor network
activity. Who is responsible? Vendors, of course, because they are shipping software. Security
department, because some vendors are very hard to cooperate, so the security department will be
responsible. Or anyone, like IOCs are being created by the community. You can pay for generating IOCs,
or you can generate them on your own and it will work. Stuff will ingest your data and you will
get the detection. Why? Because we already put some effort on, we already persuaded vendors that
are supplying us with the software to put some effort on the security. From the functionality
perspective, and if you disagree, raise a hand. Both things that I listed here, like a code signing
and a hash publication, is completely worthless. It is not adding additional security to the
software. It is adding another security layer. Code signing allows you to sign the code, and if
you download it, you are able to verify if that code was shipped and signed by this specific
holder of this certificate. From the business perspective, this is a cost, because they need
to acquire a quite costly certificate. They need to maintain the key management. They need to keep
the key safe, because if the key leaks, you get the, I don't know, Windows driver signed by the
leaked certificate. So, this is costly. And from the overall perspective, this is not improving,
I don't know, the quality of the software. The software is not running faster if it is being
signed. Hash publication. This is maybe not so cost-ineffective, because you just need to
calculate a hash of your binaries and publish them on your website, but this is an additional
process that is also not improving the efficiency of your software. This is just a security feature
that allows people, when your code is, for example, not signed, to verify if they have the right
binaries on the disk. A very simple operation. Do's and don'ts. The thing that I would like
to propose is the idea may help to improve or solve partial problems with the security,
especially in terms of shipping a third-party stuff in your infrastructure. It is just a format.
This is not an implementation. This is not a solution. I'm not creating EDR, XDR, endpoint
protection, firewall, whatever, and definitely not a blockchain. This is something like IOCs.
IOC is just a specification, how we will write the data. And definitely, this is not a silver
bullet. This will not solve all the security problems. This will help us to improve the
security and maybe fix some specific problems. Let me show you what I had in mind when I was
working on the format. We have already rules that are human and computer readable, like Sigma rules,
Yaro rules. Anybody here wrote a Swagger OpenAPI profile for your web application? Yes? You can
describe in human readable form what your whole web application is implementing, like all the
HTTP requests that can be done to your application, and you have a way to describe that. And this is
still human readable and computer readable. Rules that need to be human readable, well-structured,
you need to be able to make a very easy, in a very easy way, a diff between two files when
something is changing. And the benefit of that, you are able to store it in the repository as a
text file, so you are able to track the changes over the time. Rules in that format can, the
purpose is that those rules can be later on translated, exported, or, I don't know, compiled
to the other formats. So, for example, to AppArmor, Linux, AppLocker, Sysmon, Proxmon rules,
whatever you have in your infrastructure. AppArmor is a very good example because they
are already providing very similar functionality, but please raise a hand whoever read AppArmor
configuration file. Like, look inside. One, two. It is working, but this definitely, the part of
human readable is not working there. Like, yeah, you can take a piece of paper and start drawing
things and maybe you will understand, but this is definitely not so obvious. And let's apply some
old Python Xen. Explicit over implicit. The readability is important. If our format needs
additional explanation, this is a bad idea. So, this format needs to be easy to understand,
even for the person that didn't read this documentation for that. So, yeah, this is the
format how we will store it. The problem, of course, there's a, quickly we will pick up the
problem of signing those rules because if the vendor will be releasing them, we need to have a
way to verify the integrity of the file so we can put them into the JWT so the vendor can sign it.
Probably maybe using even the same certificate that you're using for code signing, which is
asymmetric key. And this is an example of the rule. We have very simple structure. We're defining the,
we have categories like network behavior, file system behavior. Let me show you the file itself.
Yeah, so we have some metadata like any other formats. Targets, so we are defining what files,
what, to what files should we apply this rule set to. And basically, the rule set is here. So,
for example, for network, we specify that this piece of software is allowed to connect to,
example, COM on port 80. If our solution is allowing us to implement layer 7 inspection,
we have the information that we expect HTTP there. If our solution is not allowing us to do so,
we just can leave with port TCP and only that information. On the file system, we can specify
what paths, what files can be open and accessed by the software. And the idea behind the whole
rule set is to apply the allow-deny order. So, if something is not being allowed explicitly,
it means that it is not being allowed at all. So, if you don't want your software to touch the file
system, you're just leaving the file system section empty. And basically, it means that
your software doesn't supposed to touch anything on the disk. Exec means what kind of child
processes should be allowed to be spawned by that process. Registry, this is very platform specific.
Parents means what can we expect in terms of our process being spawned from. And environment means
we can put some information what are the allowed or not allowed environment variables that are
being used by our software. This is quite basic. The format is extendable. So, we can, if we think
about like, I don't know, maybe let's add what is the current temperature in the room and the
software only needs to be operated in a specific range of temperature, we can add a section here.
Not a problem. How to generate that stuff? Vendors can use a code annotation. They are
already using code annotation to generate the documentation. Like, whoever spent some time on
developing software knows that in most modern programming languages, you can put a code
annotation in the comments in your code. And just by having them in the code, you can create a
documentation that will describe how your code is working, what API are you exposing. So, we can try
to make a code annotation. So, for example, if we have, and this is an obvious way to do that,
if we have a function that is, I don't know, loading a configuration file from the disk,
we can add a code annotation that we expect read and write access to the specific file on the disk.
Of course, we can generate that profile by sandboxing, monitoring, etc. So, we can just
list the events that are happening and add them to the whitelist. Or we can just do the
manual work. And let me show you an example of the rule. For example, a very obvious rule for notepad.
Okay. So, this is a rule for the notepad. Notepad's supposed to open read and write
files on the disk. It doesn't supposed to, I don't know, do a network communication,
spawn a process, I don't know, execute anything. Like, if you will see a notepad spawning a new
process, this is definitely not something expected from the notepad. So, in this way,
in those few lines of text, we created a profile for a notepad. A thing that is being commonly
used in very naive exploitation paths, but it will work. Later on, you can fit that knowledge
into your security solution and see, like, if there is something that is not fitting the profile,
this is definitely the indicator of being compromised. So, we're going back to the
indicator of the compromise, but we don't need to define explicitly that we are looking for
something malicious here. And let me show you an example of how we can see the changes in the file.
Okay.
Yeah, so, even if the attacker would manage to compromise the supply chain of the vendor,
and even if they manage to compromise this ION rule set, and the vendor will publish,
like, they will be, I don't know, stupid and will publish anything that will be delivered
by the pipeline. Anyone, without any reverse engineering, can take a look on that and see,
okay, somebody added a huge section here, and the software that previously, in past,
over the past five years, was not executing anything, is, like, allowed to execute arbitrary
binary from the disk. There are still some open problems, like how can we put pin policy to a
binary using hash signatures, etc. How can we handle a script interpreters or load bins? This
is an open subject. One of the ideas here is to create a pattern for what arguments for the
process are being allowed. And in terms of networking, there's always a problem in domain
name resolution versus time to check versus time to use DNS rebinding, etc. But I think those are
the minor problems here. I want to thank, to give a big thank to everybody who I asked about the
opinion or help on that subject here for over the past year. I don't want to list them because
there's, like, a huge list of the person and I may miss somebody, so big thank you to everybody
who helped me on improving that. Please feel free to contribute.
